conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light; shape and size depend on object shape and light angle.
Shadow length is inversely proportional to the height of the light source above the object.
The light source is positioned above and slightly behind the objects, casting shadows forward.
When the light source moves forward, it will be positioned more directly above the objects.
The change in light source position will affect the length and direction of the shadows.
As the light source moves forward, shadows will become shorter due to more perpendicular light rays.
The direction of shadows will change to extend more directly downward or slightly backward.
Shadow A (Glove) will become shorter and extend more directly downward or slightly backward.
Shadow B (Typewriter) will become shorter and extend more directly downward or slightly backward.
Shadow C (Bird) will become shorter and extend more directly downward or slightly backward.
Shadow D (Peaches) will become shorter and extend more directly downward or slightly backward.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will become shorter and extend more directly downward or slightly backward.
